sen.j: 楠本 高子（くすもと たかこ、嘉永5年2月7日_(旧暦)（1852年2月26日） - 昭和13年（1938年）7月18日）はフィリップ・フランツ・フォン・シーボルトの孫娘で楠本イネの娘。
sen.e: Takako KUSUMOTO (February 26, 1852-July18, 1938), the granddaughter of Philipp Franz von Siebold was the daughter of Ine KUSUMOTO.
Takako KUSUMOTO (February 26, 1852-July18, 1938) was a granddaughter of Philipp Franz von Siebold and a daughter of Ine KUSUMOTO.
Takako KUSUMOTO (February 26, 1852-July18, 1938) was a granddaughter of Philipp Franz von Siebold and a daughter of Ine KUSUMOTO.

sen.j: 結婚後の改姓により「三瀬高子（みせ たかこ）」「山脇高子（やまわき たかこ）」「山脇たか」とも言われる。
sen.e: She was called "Takako MIFUCHI", "Takako YAMAGIWA" and "Taka YAMAWAKI" due to the family name change according to her marriages.
She has been also called "Takako MISE," "Takako YAMAWAKI" and "Taka YAMAWAKI" depending on the changes her name by marriages.
sen.cmt: オリジナルに「三淵高子（みふち たかこ）」とありましたが、「三瀬（みせ）」の間違いなので直します。
sen.e: She has been also called "Takako MISE," "Takako YAMAWAKI" and "Taka YAMAWAKI" depending on the changes her name by marriages.

sen.j: 高子は不幸な出生で（詳細は「石井宗謙」の項参照）、当初は「タダ子」とよばれていた（天がただで授けたものであろう、というあきらめの境地から名付けられた）。
sen.e: Takako's birth was unfortunate (refer to "Soken ISHII") and was initially called "Tadako" (that meant a free child because she was considered a child given by God for free when her mother threw up her hands).

Takako was an unexpected baby (refer to the article of 'Soken ISHII') and she was initially called 'Tadako' (literally, 'a free child' which was named with resignation that a child was given by God for free).
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミスがあります。
sen.e: Takako was an unexpected baby (refer to the article of 'Soken ISHII') and she was initially called 'Tadako' (literally, 'a free child' which was named with resignation that a child was given by God for free).

sen.j: 13歳まで長崎市の祖母・お滝の元で育つ。
sen.e: She grew up with her grandmother, Otaki in Nagasaki City until 13.
She was brought up by her grandmother Otaki in Nagasaki City until the age of 13.
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミスがあります。
sen.e: She was brought up by her grandmother Otaki in Nagasaki City until the age of 13.

sen.j: 幼少時は琴や三味線、日本舞踊など芸事に熱心であった。
sen.e: She was keen on Japanese arts including Koto (Japanese harp), Shamisen (three-stringed Japanese banjo) and Classical Japanese dance in her girlhood.
She was keen on Japanese arts including Koto (Japanese harp), Shamisen (three-stringed Japanese banjo) and Classical Japanese dance in her girlhood.
She was keen on Japanese arts including Koto (Japanese harp), Shamisen (three-stringed Japanese banjo) and Classical Japanese dance in her girlhood.

sen.j: 医者を嗣ぐことを期待していたイネを嘆かせていたという。
sen.e: She made Ine sad because Ine expected her to be a doctor which was their family business.
She made Ine complain because Ine had expected her to become doctor which was their family business.
She made Ine complain because Ine had expected her to become doctor which was their family business.

sen.j: 14歳の時に母の師・二宮敬作の縁により宇和島藩の奥女中として奉公を始める。
sen.e: When she was 14 years old, she started working for the Uwajima Domain as a maid due to the connection with Keisaku NINOMIYA who was a teacher of her mother.
When she was 14 years old, she started serving the Uwajima clan as maid on the introduction of Keisaku NINOMIYA who was a teacher of her mother.
When she was 14 years old, she started serving the Uwajima clan as maid on the introduction of Keisaku NINOMIYA who was a teacher of her mother.
In 1866, she was married to Morobuchi MISE.
In 1866, she married Morobuchi MISE.
In 1866, she married Morobuchi MISE.

sen.j: 夫の三瀬諸淵はシーボルト門下の医者で、二宮敬作の甥に当たった。
sen.e: Her husband, Morobuchi MISE, a doctor who was a student of Siebold, was a nephew of Keisaku NINOMIYA.
Her husband Morobuchi MISE was a doctor and a pupil of Siebold, and he was also a nephew of Keisaku NINOMIYA.
Her husband Morobuchi MISE was a doctor and a pupil of Siebold, and he was also a nephew of Keisaku NINOMIYA.

sen.j: 1877年に夫・三瀬諸淵に先立たれた後、異母兄・石井信義の元で産婦人科を学んだ。
sen.e: After she lost her husband, Morobuchi MISE in 1877, she studied gynecology under the instruction of her half brother, Nobuyoshi ISHI.
After her husband Morobuchi MISE had died in 1877, she studied gynecology from her half brother Nobuyoshi ISHI.
After her husband Morobuchi MISE had died in 1877, she studied gynecology from her half brother Nobuyoshi ISHI.

sen.j: しかし、その中で医師・片桐重明との間に周三（後にイネの養子）を生む事態となり、医業の道は断念した。
sen.e: However, she gave up to be a doctor because she was pregnant with a boy, Shuzo (who was later adapted to Ine) by a doctor, Shigeaki KATAGIRI.
However, during the study, she became pregnant with Shuzo (later adapted to Ine) by a doctor Shigeaki KATAGIRI, so she gave up the idea of studying medicine.
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミスがあります。
sen.e: However, during the study, she became pregnant with Shuzo (later adapted to Ine) by a doctor Shigeaki KATAGIRI, so she gave up the idea of studying medicine.

sen.j: その直後に医師・山脇泰助と再婚、一男二女を生むが、結婚7年目に先立たれた。
sen.e: Right after being pregnant, she was remarried to a doctor, Taisuke YAMAWAKI and had a son and two daughters, however her second husband, Taisuke died 7 years later after their marriage.
Soon after that, she remarried a doctor Taisuke YAMAWAKI and they had a son and two daughters, however, Taisuke also died only seven years after they had married.
Soon after that, she remarried a doctor Taisuke YAMAWAKI and they had a son and two daughters, however, Taisuke also died only seven years after they had married.

sen.j: その後は叔父のハインリッヒ・フォン・シーボルトの世話を受け、東京で母のイネと共に暮らした。
sen.e: She was then supported by her uncle, Heinrich von Siebold and lived with her mother, Ine in Tokyo.
After that, she was supported by her uncle Heinrich von Siebold and lived with her mother Ine in Tokyo.
After that, she was supported by her uncle Heinrich von Siebold and lived with her mother Ine in Tokyo.

sen.j: 以後は幼少時に熱心だった芸事の教授をして生計を立てていた。
sen.e: After that, she earned her living out of teaching the Japanese arts which she was keen on in her girlhood.
And in Tokyo she earned her living from teaching the Japanese arts which she had learned keenly in her girlhood.
And in Tokyo she earned her living from teaching the Japanese arts which she had learned keenly in her girlhood.

sen.j: 松本零士の先祖が三瀬諸淵の同僚で、高子と会いとても印象に残った。
sen.e: When Takako met Reiji MATSUMOTO's ancestor who was a colleague of Morobuchi MISE, she left a strong impression on him.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: When Takako met Reiji MATSUMOTO's ancestor who was a colleague of Morobuchi MISE, she left a strong impression on him.
When Takako met Reiji MATSUMOTO's ancestor who was a colleague of Morobuchi MISE, she left a strong impression on him.

sen.j: その話を零士が聞き継いだ為に、無意識に作品に出てくる女性のモデルとなっていたと松本零士自身が語っている。（コスモウォーリアー零 外伝 2より）
sen.e: Reiji MATSUMOTO said that he unconsciously used Takako as a woman model in his stories due to the story of his ancestor when he met her.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Reiji MATSUMOTO said that since he had heard that ancestor's story, he unconsciously used Takako as a model for female characters of his works (cited "Cosmo Warrior Zero, Side Story 2").
sen.cmt: 文法ミス、訳語選択ミスがあります。
sen.e: Reiji MATSUMOTO said that since he had heard that ancestor's story, he unconsciously used Takako as a model for female characters of his works (cited "Cosmo Warrior Zero, Side Story 2").

sen.j: 2008年現在、本人の手記が公開されている。
sen.e: In 2008, her personal notes were released.
As of 2008, her personal notes are exhibited.
sen.cmt: 訳語選択ミスがあります。
sen.e: As of 2008, her personal notes are exhibited.
